title: So summing up the changes we have in the Mt. Targon lore
body:
{{champion:80}} : 

* Whilst human was named "Atreus"
* Was always second best but hard working and determined (Atreus is now Naruto; BELIEVE IT!)
* No longer bakes
* No longer friends with Leona, attempted to rat Leona out for saving a "monster" of the mountain and nearly dueled her to the death
* Hated the Solari
* Given the god like powers of the constellation "Pantheon" the aspect of war
* Personality obliterated and replaced with "Pantheon"


{{champion:89}} 

* Has no qualms about killing over protecting anymore
* No longer childhood friends with Pantheon
* Saved a winged child (Aurelion Sol human form confirmed EDIT: Not actually confirmed, its a joke guys) and dueled Atreus before being inducted into the Solari
* Complete zealot in her Solari beliefs
* Seriously, like willing to murder Diana over her Lunari speech, kept herself alive on Mt. Targon using hate fuel.
* Infused with Aspect of the Sun, personality retained but given ancient knowledge
* Wants to find Diana to share in their newfound knowledge (and hopefully not murder her).
 
{{champion:131}} 

* Adopted by the Solari as a child when her parents died on Mt. Targon
* Infused with Aspect of the Moon on the summit; personality retained but given ancient knowledge and memories of past lives
* No longer totally down for murdering everyone (Leona adopted that I guess)
* Wants to work WITH the Solari
* Kills void creatures at night like a badass


So what do you all think? Did I miss anything? Anything to add? Questions, comments and discussion on the changes encouraged.

Personally I find it strange that Leona was such a Solari zealot, something that was endearing about her personality was how she favored protecting people over harming them and this was not seen in the lore rework. With how open they left her lore entry it could be assumed that after being infused with the aspect of the sun she is no longer trying to hardcore murder Diana but that was left rather open to interpretation.

On the Pantheon side of things I liked it almost in its entirety, the only thing I found myself worrying about was how the personality of Atreus was apparently completely wiped out to be replaced with "Pantheon"

As for Diana I liked her lore entry in its entirety, it was exactly what I was expecting. Kept the good parts of the old lore and built upon them, making her seem more relatable and good character. The only downside of this is that it doesn't translate as well to her edgy in game persona.

Why spend a while story describing the guy then say "and he was gone forever... now your hero is.... SOME NEW GUY!  Or a god?  Maybe? And Leona was THE champion of the weak and the most lawful good of champions... save maybe Braum.  Now she's a zealot and a murderer. Welcome to league of generic badasses.  Just assume they're all gods or something.  Next up... the epic story of Zaun, in which the god of rats and the god of flubber face the god of spamming laugh and the god of going where he pleases!

My hope is that this is all meant to set up some sort of major lore event where Leona becomes a truly compassionate person and Atreus regains himself from Pantheon. Remember, Gangplank started out as the ruler of Bilgewater but then became a man bent on revenge and reclaiming all he lost.

I'm not at all involved with the new stories, so standard Bioluminescence disclaimer applies (not part of Narrative, etc.) but this line turned my stomach and removed a lot of the sympathy I might have had for the raiders:

> The leader raised a callused hand as he saw a lone figure standing athwart the settlementâs street. He grinned as he saw **it was a woman. Finally, something worth plundering**.

There were 50 of them, all warriors (not a mixed group of warriors, craftspeople, elderly and the young).  Their job was sweeping from settlement to settlement (not military outpost to military outpost) and taking anything they pleased.  The settlements weren't even wealthy, according to the description - they were going after soft targets, and not through need.

> The previous settlements had been easily overcome; little challenge for men weaned on battle. The spoils were few and far between, but in this strange land, a man took what he could get.

In a more enlightened age (ha!) you might argue you'd capture these people and try them before a jury - maybe attempt rehabilitation.  But I'm not sure how big Runeterra is on that.  Each one was guilty by their leaders own thought process, each one is implied to have murdered (and more) the defenseless, the poor, the innocents.  If in Leona's mind, her options were to either kill these men, or let them rape and pillage again, then her choice would be clear.  Do you think that if she let them run off, they'd all go back home and become goatherds?  Or would they look for soft targets elsewhere.

Kinda like in Gundam Seed, where Kira stops killing and only disarms enemy MS's (with some rare exceptions like Rau or Durandal).

But by crippling then you have the problem of dealing with said crippling lounging on your region: you find yourself to have to take care of the scum of humanity ( because someone has to deal with cripples ) while these plot to take over your/ has resentment toward your community. Or maybe having to sacrifice valorous men to take time and care to not kill but cripple, while maybe at the end of the battle all the effort to cripple becomes vain since many can' t afford immediate medical aid, basically causing them just a far worse kind of death.

They could have taken hostages, but that probably was unpractical too. Probably they did that, however - in these kind of narrations you have to not say everything, or else you flood the reader with tons of inconsequential information. Still, that would have been a secondary priority.

Also, about your example, i think that it' s just a different scenario: this is not an "heroic" 1v1, this is war.
Umm, why would Leona and company take care of the cripples? Wouldn't it be "let them rot"?

I might have misunderstood you on that, so clear me out if i am wrong. If they had hypothetically a scenario where Leona and her little army cripples every one of the bandits, what would happen next?

Those war-bent mercenaries probably do not have a home to return to, probably they could even not because they are crippled and can' t stand a long travel home, or even a short one. Now Leona finds herself with a mob of crippled formerly hostile mercenaries stranded at her home. If she takes care of them then she has to put a toll into her population by feeding them and helping them to at least survive, with these giving back hate and angst, in order to let them become civils with nothing but warlike experience with the risk of having them become bandits ( poorly performing one, but still); if she just leaves them be, they would probably die by themselves, obtaining the same result as killing them only in a more painful way that would probably cost a lot of her soldiers.

So, why would she ever want to cripple them in first place?
Maybe it's an "out of principle" thing, and she goes with "you brought it on yourselves" if they die to the elements as a result.

I'm not sure there's a clearly 'right and good' answer to this one, but to me, the lesser of the two evils would be giving the raiders a quick clean death; likely better than they gave their earlier victims.  The alternative being a slow death to infection, exposure, starvation and dehydration, possible animal attacks or even cannibalism.

A vindictive person might say they deserve it.  A pragmatic person would want to remove their ability to cause more harm with the least collatoral loss possible.

Reality check, though - this is us trying to rationalize the actions of a character set in a brutal, very un-modern, setting.  What might seem horrific to us, might be relatively merciful.  Then again, this is a piece of fiction, and as brutal and horrific as its writers decree.  It's all relative!

I've been watching the discussion, not really wanting to stick my oar in while folks are debating, particularly as I often feel even when I tip-toe in here it sounds like clogs and I don't want to say anything considered definitive to who the champions are and will be.

I'd also recommend listening to the podcast in full, I think it's telling how Ant is particular in talking about possibility when it comes to Targon and the champs moving forward. These Champs aren't locked in stone. The roster hasn't even been fully revealed yet. And while there are some changes to the Champs, (I think Pantheon has changed the most, personally), it is the story moving forward, in the years ahead that will define them.

The new Character Intros, which we hope you like, are not meant to be the comprehensive view of who they are and who they could ever be. Though for those who believe Leona can no longer be a protector of others, I do think seeds have been planted quite firmly.

I'll talk to that elsewhere though.

Jaredan, the podcast is an hour long. I realize I may be alone in this, but I don't want to listen to a podcast for an hour.

(And you may want to avoid using the word 'years' to refer to future lore stories. It, uh, sets an expectation for your release schedule, how fast it's (not) going.)

EDIT: Okay, I went and listened to it.

That could not have been a more 'lore team' pod cast than if it tried. 'We're looking for more ways to tell stories!' 'We're trying to make something for everyone!' 'My favorite region is whatever we're working on!'

And yes, I know it's a bunch of Rioters talking to a bunch of other Rioters; it never could have gotten particularly critical. But seriously, that was basically just an hour of talking about how great the lore team is and how cool the Targon event is and how great the next lore stories will be, interspersed with a lot of 'What's YOUR favorite region?'

Maybe listening to it while I'm already annoyed and am about to go to bed was a bad idea, but that was not all that interesting.

It seems a little rude of them to have no system in place to inform everyone at Riot what's new in the game. 

Maybe you could send word to the higher ups that there needs to be a way in client to give real feedback. The forums make up a very, very small number of players, so they never get enough data. Maybe even a tab for the forums in the actual client. 

It would also be fair to the players who do come here to make a sticky at the top of every board reminding people that the boards are-- as stated by multiple Riot employees in multiple threads-- NOT for communication with Riot, but supposedly for communication between players. 

And since you probably don't know this, either (don't see why you'd need to before now):
it needs to be known that if you try to actually talk about the game with Support, they'll reference you to the forums, while if you call out the people in charge of the forums, they'll tell you to go to Support with your requests. It's just a loop to keep players from actually interacting with the company.

> [{quoted}](name=Bioluminescence,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Q7Ib28xy,comment-id=000a000000010000,timestamp=2016-02-26T18:47:48.172+0000)
>
> I'm not at all involved with the new stories, so standard Bioluminescence disclaimer applies (not part of Narrative, etc.) but this line turned my stomach and removed a lot of the sympathy I might have had for the raiders:

Why would you need sympathy for raiders? They're raiders. Let alone the fact that they are set up as the villains in this setting, the issue has never been about whether the reader likes the raiders, but about how far the protagonist's values and principles reach.

Also yes, raiders, mainly male in historical times and the fictional settings they inspire, were getting their rocks off with women of towns they plundered. Not that I expect everyone to withstand the thought of violent rape without feeling the urge to hurl but can we be honest and realize that having a dick inside you is really not the worst thing that can happen to you as a victim of a raid? (take a shot, anyone who had to read that last word twice).

> There were 50 of them, all warriors (not a mixed group of warriors, craftspeople, elderly and the young).  Their job was sweeping from settlement to settlement (not military outpost to military outpost) and taking anything they pleased.  The settlements weren't even wealthy, according to the description - they were going after soft targets, and not through need.

So basically...raiders? Seriously, raiding tribes had no CEO, there was no calculation of profit margin. And from that perspective you naturally go for targets that have a very little chance of costing you troops.
> 
> In a more enlightened age (ha!) you might argue you'd capture these people and try them before a jury - maybe attempt rehabilitation.  But I'm not sure how big Runeterra is on that.  Each one was guilty by their leaders own thought process, each one is implied to have murdered (and more) the defenseless, the poor, the innocents.  If in Leona's mind, her options were to either kill these men, or let them rape and pillage again, then her choice would be clear.  Do you think that if she let them run off, they'd all go back home and become goatherds?  Or would they look for soft targets elsewhere.

Thing is that this deep focus on the "innocence" of a criminal's victim is pretty much a byproduct of our more "ha" enlightened age. In a "Survival of the strongest"-setting (not fittest), bandits, who garner their power and resources through pillaging and theft, would DEFINITELY go for those "poor, defenseless people", because it makes no sense to go up against well-trained, well equipped, battlehardened opponents.
You're judging their actions and logic through values and principles that would be idiotic at best and suicidal at worst for people like these.
Granted, that doesn't make them any more sympathetic and as stated before, they don't have to be. It's just that given the kinds of characters we're facing here and the setting they're supposedly in, that kind of view of them is...funny, to say the least.
> 
> 
> _(Standard disclaimer - I know no more than you guys do.  I only read the stories for the first time yesterday too.  I think part of the issue with the new Targon stories is that Leona isn't so easily and immediately likable now.  She's unpleasant in ways, much as any zealot might be, before her world shattering revelation.)_

I'd wager that the issue is less her being "instantly likeable" but that what characterized Leona so far is pretty much gone. And the fact that her "character change" was pretty much delivered with the hammer of the gods doesn't help the least bit.
The old Leona held up her values and believes from a position of weakness and against overwhelming opposition. She would've been killed for them, too, if the whole sunbeam thing didn't occur. But that danger is exactly what made her upholding her values so memorable.

Upholding lofty values and beliefs is always easy after you've been blessed with the knowledge and power of a demigod. 

Also, to the whole "they might kill again, so better kill them"-point: I think almost every DC- AND Marvel-Superhero likes to have a word with you. ^^
Not trying to be rude, but that mentality certainly has its flaws. God knows how many people the Joker has killed after escaping Arkham for the 943rd time

Pantheon and Leona still had very opposing approaches, as stated in Pantheon's lore. Pantheon wanted a more proactive approach of eliminating threats before they became a problem. Leona was more about strengthening the defenses to repel outsider aggression. It is only natural for Pantheon to dislike the Solari when they clearly sided with Leona's approach of handling matters.

I'm not too upset over Leona's lore changes. There have been many remarks about her reaction to Diana, but it does not take into account the history between the two. Leona took her teachings at face value without any interest in alternate means of power. Diana inherently knew there was more truth and openly pursued it. There's a boundary between questioning a teaching and challenging authority which Diana clearly crossed often enough to cause her isolation from her peers.

Diana disappeared for months and returned a different person. She bore a mark and the color of her hair had been drained. A trouble maker returned with an aura of power. There is a limit to how much trust anyone could possess in such circumstances, and Leona's reaction does not disappoint. She allows a potential threat to have an audience with the elders. Yes, she was angry with Diana's words. This was a child raised in the temple of the sun that decided it would be better to seek power from the moon. How foolish. How naive. A lost lamb had returned but was more lost now than ever before. Even Leona would realize these words would result in execution. How much more interesting things would have been if the two had known each other on a more personal level.

But she lets Diana speak it all, despite knowing the outcome. She waits for the order in a state of unspecified anger. I don't know if there were rules that dictated her behavior or if there was some prideful assumption that Diana was not a threat and could not escape. It feels contradictory to the evidence before their eyes.

In my mind, the elders are a counsel. Think of something like a long table with a bunch of old men seated on one side and looking down upon Diana. The rejection of her words would not come all at once. There would be a span of almost a minute where every single one of them would denounce her. One or two rejections would not be nearly as overwhelming as six or more. Diana would be reeling and at a loss. There needs to be a time for fury to build up over this unreasonable denial of the truth. That's plenty of time for Leona to react, but she still waits for an official order from the elders. That window of opportunity closes when Diana impulsively lashes out.

People can cry over her murderous rage, but Leona failed thoroughly in defending and protecting her elders. She failed because she allowed Diana too many chances. That's devastating. It doesn't take much to place the deaths of the elders on her own shoulders. Rage is all that can prevent her from breaking entirely down.
